title: How to Freeze Pasta

parts.name: Prepping the Pasta for the Freezer

steps.headline: Cook the noodles for 2 minutes less than usual.
steps.description: The length of cooking time will vary depending on what type of pasta you are cooking. Fill a pot with boiling water and carefully add the pasta. Regardless of what type of pasta you’re using, leave the noodles to cook until they are al dente. This allows the pasta to be edible if it is thawed naturally and stops it from going mushy if it is reheated. Set a timer to help remind you to check the pasta. Cook penne pasta for about 9 minutes. Cook spaghetti for about 7 minutes.

steps.headline: Drain the pasta and leave it to cool for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Carefully pour the pasta into a colander and wait for all the water to drain. Transfer the pasta back into the pot and leave it so cool for 5 minutes. This helps to keep it from sweating in its container.

steps.headline: Stir a dash of olive oil through the noodles.
steps.description: Pour 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil over the noodles. This helps to stop them from sticking together and makes them easier to thaw. Use a spoon to gently stir the oil through the noodles. Use extra-virgin olive oil to achieve the optimal taste and nutritional benefits. If you want to add sauce to your noodles, it is best to freeze it separately in an airtight container.

steps.headline: Transfer the pasta into an airtight container if you want a quick option.
steps.description: Use tongs or a spoon to transfer the noodles into a freezer-safe airtight container. This helps to prevent the pasta from getting freezer burn.

steps.headline: Flash-freeze the pasta if you want smaller portions.
steps.description: Measure ½ cup (75 gram) portions of pasta onto a baking tray that is lined with parchment paper. Place the tray into the freezer for 15 minutes for the bundles of the pasta to stick together. Remove the bundles and place them all into a freezer bag for easy storage.

steps.headline: Leave the pasta in the freezer for up to 2 weeks.
steps.description: Place the airtight container into the freezer. Write the date onto the container with a permanent marker to help remember when it was frozen. If you want to eat the pasta in the next few days, leave it in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.

steps.headline: Reheat the pasta on the stovetop if you want it to taste fresh.
steps.description: Boil a pot of water on the stove top. Once the water is boiling, carefully drop the frozen noodles into the water using a pair of tongs. Leave the frozen noodles in the boiling water for 30 seconds to reheat. Use a fork to remove a noodle and check that it is thawed. If the noodle is nice and soft, remove the pot from the heat and then drain the noodles. If the noodles aren’t completely thawed after 30 seconds, cook them for a further 15 seconds in the boiling water.

steps.headline: Thaw the pasta in the microwave for 90 seconds if you want a quick option.
steps.description: This is the fastest and easiest way to thaw the noodles. Simply place the noodles in a microwave-safe container. Place the lid over the container but don’t press it down. This will help keep the pasta moist and stop any oil from spitting into the microwave. Turn the container around after 45 seconds if your microwave doesn’t have a turning wheel.

steps.headline: Leave the pasta to thaw naturally if you plan to eat it later in the day.
steps.description: Frozen pasta makes an incredibly easy lunch or dinner. Take the pasta out of the freezer in the morning. If you are having the pasta for lunch, leave it at room temperature to thaw. If you are eating the pasta for dinner, leave the noodles in the fridge to thaw. The noodles will only be cooked to al dente using this method. This means that they will not be as soft as if you had reheated them. If you want softer noodles, simply mix the pasta into a hot sauce.
